question.text: When two resistance <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> connected in series and introduced into the left gap of a meter bridge and a resistance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math> is introduced into the right gap, a null point is found at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>60</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cm</mi></math> from left side. When <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are connected in parallel and introduced into the left gap, a resistance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math> is introduced into the right-gap to get null point at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn><mo> </mo><mi>cm</mi></math> from left end. The product of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo> </mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is ______ <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>

solution.text:
A meter bridge consists of a wire of length 1 m and of uniform cross-sectional area stretched taut and clamped between two thick metallic strips bent at right angles with two gaps across which resistors are to be connected. It works on the principle of the Wheatstone bridge. Therefore, we can write

R1+R210=6040⇒R1+R2=15 Ω

Then for the second case, we can write 

R1R2R1+R2×3=4060⇒R1R2=30 Ω2
